revision.text: {{talk header}} {{ArticleHistory |action1=GAN |action1date=06:56, 19 May 2010 |action1link=Talk:SMS Baden (1915)/GA1 |action1result=listed |action1oldid=362963264 |action2=GTC |action2date=15:44, 27 June 2010 (UTC) |action2link=Wikipedia:Featured topic candidates/Bayern class battleships/archive1 |action2result=promoted |action2oldid=370257416 |action3=WAR |action3date=10:20, 9 July 2010 (UTC) |action3link=Wikipedia:WikiProject Military history/Assessment/SMS Baden (1915) |action3result=approved |action3oldid=370257416 |action4=FAC |action4date=13:47, 5 October 2010 |action4link=Wikipedia:Featured article candidates/SMS Baden (1915)/archive1 |action4result=promoted |action4oldid=388254276 |action5=GTC |action5date=02:55, 25 August 2011 |action5link=Wikipedia:Featured topic candidates/Battleships of Germany/archive1 |action5result=promoted |ftname=Battleships of Germany |topic=history |dykdate=21 May 2010 |dykentry=... that the German [[dreadnought battleship]] ''[[SMS Baden (1915)|SMS ''Baden'']]''' was the only [[capital ship]] not successfully sunk in the [[scuttling of the German fleet in Scapa Flow]] in 1919? |currentstatus=FA |maindate=26 June 2011 |four=no }} {{WikiProjectBannerShell|1= {{WikiProject Ships|class=FA}} {{WPMILHIST|class=FA|Maritime=yes|German=yes|WWI=yes|A-Class=pass|OMT=1}} {{WikiProject Germany|class=FA|importance=low}} }} The photo is of SMS Bayern not Baden, there's no admirals bridge as proof. — Preceding [[Wikipedia:Signatures|unsigned]] comment added by [[User:Tankterror|Tankterror]] ([[User talk:Tankterror|talk]] • [[Special:Contributions/Tankterror|contribs]]) 08:45, 18 June 2016 (UTC) ==Design== "The design of the Baden carried over into the Bismarck." As this statement is incorrect and contradicted by the "Bayern Class" generic article, I have deleted it. Although the Bismarck class had some common features, such as the main armament disposition, it was no more based upon the Bayern Class design than it was on the Kaisers, Konigs or similar British designs like the Queen Elizabeths or R class... [[User:84.92.80.169|84.92.80.169]] 14:35, 21 November 2006 (UTC) == Scapa Flow == Looking this over for DYK...it almost seems as if there's a complete paragraph missing at the end of the Scapa Flow section? The narrative jumps right from Reuter issuing the scuttling order, to the next section with the ship arriving in Invergordon, and there's noting in between... - [[User:The Bushranger|The Bushranger]] [[User talk:The Bushranger|Return fire]][[User:The Bushranger/Pages Created|''Flank speed'']] 22:41, 12 May 2010 (UTC) :Thanks for catching that, it somehow must have slipped my mind when I was writing it. I've added a couple of sentences to bridge the gap. [[User:Parsecboy|Parsecboy]] ([[User talk:Parsecboy|talk]]) 23:01, 12 May 2010 (UTC) ::No worries. Much better now. :) - [[User:The Bushranger|The Bushranger]] [[User talk:The Bushranger|Return fire]][[User:The Bushranger/Pages Created|''Flank speed'']] 15:57, 13 May 2010 (UTC) {{Talk:SMS Baden (1915)/GA1}} ==Baden trials== Somewhat off topic: The Baden firing trials are of considerable interest to the naval history community but the complete & collated results thereof are not easily found on the web. Something to add here maybe? —Preceding [[Wikipedia:Signatures|unsigned]] comment added by [[Special:Contributions/194.75.48.5|194.75.48.5]] ([[User talk:194.75.48.5|talk]]) 11:54, 19 July 2010 (UTC) :There is a summary account of the trials here. If you want the information on every shell hit, the article by William Schleihauf is available for viewing on Google Books [http://books.google.com/books?id=dytTKHJ0_mUC&pg=PA81&dq=baden+trials&hl=en&ei=lUBETI3aFIaBlAf0-5m1DQ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CCUQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=baden%20trials&f=false here]. [[User:Parsecboy|Parsecboy]] ([[User talk:Parsecboy|talk]]) 12:11, 19 July 2010 (UTC) ==Helgoland or Heligoland?== There are several instances of "Helgoland" in the article; the links direct to the "Heligoland" article. Is this a variant spelling? If so, then we should use the more predominant "Heligoland" unless there is a compelling reason, specific to the context of the usage in this article, to use the variant. If it's just an error, it should be corrected. [[User:HolyT|Holy]] ([[User talk:HolyT|talk]]) 16:54, 26 June 2011 (UTC) :Helgoland is the German spelling - given that it's a German island, and this article is about a German warship, I felt the German spelling was more appropriate (especially since there are contemporary ships named after the island - {{SMS|Helgoland}}, for instance). [[User:BB-PB|Parsecboy]] ([[User_talk:BB-PB|talk]]) 17:00, 26 June 2011 (UTC) ::That makes sense. Thanks! [[User:HolyT|Holy]] ([[User talk:HolyT|talk]]) 18:32, 26 June 2011 (UTC) ==Comparison to the Royal Sovereign class== The passage "The ship was found to have been approximately as efficient as the British {{sclass|Royal Sovereign|battleship|1}}s.Goodall, p. 15" must be incorrect, as the class was of pre-dreadnought battleships of the British Royal Navy. Presumely, Goodall refers to the '''battleship''' Royal Sovereign, which was of the Revenge class. The class is, indeed, sometimes referred to by the name of the last ship of the class. To confuse, the word R-class is also used. Nevertheless, the link points to the article of a pre-dreadnought battleship build in 1889–1894 and decommissioned by the time Baden was laid down. — Preceding [[Wikipedia:Signatures|unsigned]] comment added by [[User:91.217.248.11|91.217.248.11]] ([[User talk:91.217.248.11|talk]] • [[Special:Contributions/91.217.248.11|contribs]]) :Thanks for finding that - I'm not sure how no one else noticed that during the reviews, etc. [[User:Parsecboy|Parsecboy]] ([[User talk:Parsecboy|talk]]) 15:10, 27 June 2011 (UTC)
